item_category: The Galaxy Note20 Ultra puts productivity and play in the palm of your hands. It's got Microsoft Office integration, so you can create, upload and download documents on the go. You can even take notes with S Pen and convert them to Microsoft Word, at a touch. A pro-grade camera lets you take stunning shots and 8K video – then edit them to perfection. It's serious about gaming too, with console level gameplay and controller compatibility.

review_text: What a device. Functions superbly, however video recording at 50x can only be done holding the shutter button in photo mode. Some apps do not keep the colour tone of the light/dark mode, for instance, opening an app with the phone in dark mode, sometimes parts of it will revert to light mode. A simple toggle of the dark mode selection fixes this. Sometimes, apps fail to open up to the while screen and again, you have to toggle full screen app mode, even if the app isn't selected for full screen operation. The performance of the device though is phenomenal, however the s pen isn't great for left handed people, who tend to rest a part of the writing hand on the screen. These are only minor concerns, which are forgotten about with the fantastic performance of the device.

Until now I have always had apple phones. I have to say I'm more than impressed. I chose the note because of stylus, it's got great uses, I especially like if you need to jot down a quick note, you literally take phone from pocket, pull stylus out and write on screen, it saves as a note instantly. There's so many useful features with Samsung like it comes with Microsoft office, how you can personalize your phone is fabulous. I love how the screen curves. It's nice and big, which is great. The camera is just amazing. I even love the sound effects and ringtone choices. I've had it over a month and it hasn't glitched yet. I'm very very impressed especially compared to my previous iPhone 11.

I love the phone but why does it cost so much? Why make cheaper stripped down versions of the same phone which take up more resources and money to design? I've always had a note but my next phone will probably not be a note and may not be a Samsung.

The device in itself is excellent, very user friendly for such a powerful device however the battery life could be a little better. One disappointment is after receiving the one ui 3.0 update google discover is still missing and Samsung said they have no immediate plans to introduce this to the UK market.

Overall this phone is by far the most tremendous bit of kit I have had in years!

I have searched through all available settings and cannot find a solution as of yet.

Besides this one very minor inconvenience, the phone is extremely impressive and I can only look towards the future of Samsung with excitement.

Having been a huge note series fan since the Note 4, I have had every update since. I have always been impressed with the new features introduced in each new series and much is the same with this compared to the Note 10 plus.

The camera is a huge stand out compared to the note 10 plus. I found myself reaching for my DSLR instead of using the camera on most occasions, but since getting the note 20 ultra...I've hardly picked up my DSLR! 

The only real draw back for me is that despite the better battery on paper, I find myself running out much quicker than I ever did on the note 10 plus. Plus I have had the odd glitch here and there which stopped me being able to use the screen altogether without restarting the phone. Not to mention the immense frustration of listening to music on the new buds live, but getting interrupted by a call and on returning to listening to music...I find it is playing through the earpiece on my phone - have to restart the phone to get the buds to connect properly again! I didn't experience any of that even once on the old note 10.

One feature I will forever miss, which was introduced from the note 10 onwards, is the iris scanner. I loved that on the note 9 and I just don't trust the face scanner after testing it with a picture of myself and being able to unlock the phone. Such a shame we lose this due to maximising screen size.

All-in-all though...I love my note 20 ultra! In spite of the missing bits mentioned above and that's because of the great things it brings with it.

I had the Note 9, bypassed the 10 and went for the Note 20 Ultra.  Why wouldn't I?  All reviews said the phone is a monster and they were right.  

So the S20 Ultra camera blows the Note 20's out of the water but for this powerhouse, it makes little difference.  The quality I see is not that much different to the S20's camera and in honesty, even the 50x zoom is so sensitive it needs a solid base to work from if you're using it.

Screen quality is exceptional - it's the bit I look at for games and for work so it's the most important bit.  Sitting at 50% brightness keeps battery life and still provides enough for a perfect image indoors.  

Sound quality is as good as it gets for tiny little speakers hidden in a phone, stereo is surprisingly good and once hooked up to Bluetooth speakers or headphones, up goes the volume accordingly.

Connection to WiFi, Bluetooth devices and the Galaxy Watch 3 is a matter of seconds, stable connection - so far never lost a connection.  Links to my car within moments of getting in and with the Google Auto App, sat nav is photo image instant update accurate. 

Any issues?  Google Auto does not disconnect fully causing Spotify to fire up seemingly at random after getting out from the car.  Not sure if this Spotify, Google Auto or the phone but it only ever happened with the Note 20 Ultra.  That's all.  The rest is a big thumbs up from me!  he phone is awesome and with a Galaxy Watch, it just gets better.

The phone has some amazing features and runs really fast and smoothly. Although, one BIG drawback is the battery- the battery drains faster than a bucket with a hole in it. I've changed my battery settings, to save battery life, but limits the CPU speed and other features. And even on power mode I'm still losing 8% in 15 minutes. A new phone should not drain this quickly, and it's really limiting the functionality of the phone. Would not recommend.

Having had a note 9 previously I had an idea of what to expect. There are so many improvements with this one though I dont know if ill ever find them all. Very easy to use, brilliant screen and the camera is awesome. Size wise it is a big phone but thats fine with me and I prefer that. Overall easy to use, android gives you so much more usability than ios and I'm very happy. Fast processor and operating system means I have used this for most things rather than my pc or tablet. Looks good too. Only gripe I could have is the connection to the Bluetooth buds, after a day or so it seems to start breaking up. I've tried all the solutions I've found on the Web and help pages but not fixed. Plug in earphones are fine so I'm thinking it must be the Bluetooth connection. My note 9 was the same and its no different with either buds plus or the new live ones. Hopefully there will be a fix for it sooner rather than later. That apart pretty much perfect.

120hz makes 60 hz displays feel choppy now. The low latency of the pens is excellent and feels great. The removal of the Bixby button while a shame to lose a custom button was a good move while the rest of the buttons are better placed. Now a few down sides. 
It's amazing how a phone with such a big battery can have such poor battery idle battery life. The screen on battery isn't great but would be liveable with if the idle battery wasn't worse than my 2 year old Note 9 with a well worn and damaged by over heating battery (admittedly my fault but does make my point stronger). The phone spends a lot of time warm even when not in use while the battery usage gives no indication anything is using the battery. My Note 9 would finish a day on 60 to 40% this needs is 15 to 0%. The glass front and back panels make it feel like your holding a bar of soap, a skin or case is a must and thats before you get to the massive camera bump that makes the phone almost unusable on a flat surface it should have been in the centre. The screen is great its just a shame the edge give you phantom taps all the time and when unlocking will give you the something is covering the screen error all the time when nothing is touching it. Samsungs cameras are clearly good and getting better, the phone seems to actually use the different lens this time while my Note 9 often said it was while just digitally zooming in but the software still doesn't handle noise reduction and sharpening very well. Also the Note 20 Ultra likes to over expose shots and priorities too slower shutter blurring images to keep the ISO low. Which I can only assume is because the noise reduction still isn't up to scratch. The 50x digital zoom should have never been added however it is so poor quality it can only be used for marketing and nothing else. There are still many unnecessary animations like the one that takes 7 seconds to put the phone battery saving mode while on pretty much any other phone is instant, I wouldn't mind if trying to skip it didn't cancel turning it on. I also don't need to know the setting power saving is going to use when going into it, that's what the settings menu is for. Multi window and floating windows used to be very very good on the Note series but now takes too many extra taps and isn't nearly as accessible with Samsungs current UI. The price this year is also well off the Note 20 is the price Ultra should be while the normally Note 20 has been ham stringed unnecessarily and priced like a fruit based device. With the price as it is and the lack of headphone jack on a flag ship phone which is meant to be the Ultra can do everything phone makes me wonder why I stayed with Samsung. The pen as great as it is isn't enough anymore. Final side note I've lost over 9% of battery just writing this review the phone isn't doing anything else.

I have to admit, I was rather underwhelmed with the Note20 Ultra. This is the first Note I've ever owned and I upgraded from an S9+. And other than the stylus and the screen size, there really wasn't that much difference between the two in terms of innovation or speed.

I expected tons of new & exclusive features in settings but there was hardly any. The only 'unique' features off the top of my head come in the form of settings and apps that make use of the stylus. Everything else was in the settings of my S9+.

Another problem I've noticed is that the screen can randomly freeze whilst typing, using Chrome or the in-built browser. You have to minimise the screen then maximise it again for the screen/webpage to unfreeze. I have no idea what causes this and other people have experienced this issue too.

All in all, it's a really nice phone with a nice screen size etc although I'm not a big fan of the camera protruding from the back. I'm always anxious that I'll damage or scratch it when I put the phone down on a hard surface. I guess I just expected a little more WOW for the price having upgraded from the S9+ that's all.

The 5x zoom is good when you actually need to zoom to that level but I was hoping that the zoom would be used from 2x-5x but it is blurry at 4.9x for instance then you can clearly see it switch to 5x and becomes clearer. For the massive bulge that makes the phone heavier this is a shame.

Let me start with the good. Setting up my new Galaxy Note 20 Ultra and transferring all my data was simple. Installing the sim and SD card were as easy as any other phones I've used. Once up and running the phone didn't fail to deliver. The screen is crisp and bright, the buttons, all 3 of them, give a nice positive feel when used, the front facing camera is easily ignored even though it intrudes into the screen space. As a person with hearing difficulties I found the sound settings easy to set up to meet my needs. The main cameras capture clean images, even in poor light. Best of all the battery lasts ages and you're not left scrabbling about for a charger half way through the day. Also there doesn't appear to be any noticeable slow down even with lots of apps r nning. I love the copper colour and the matching ear buds, which I can wear with my hearing aids.

As for the bad bits.... They moved the stylus holder to the other side of the phone! The only other minor gripes I have are the fingerprint sensor isn't as good as others I've used. Although it's better than the one on the back, that really annoyed me. Other things, they've removed the heart rate sensor, which is a shame. I also don't find the sylus as easy to use and I used to use it a lot, it just feels more quirky and unpredictable. The air actions with the stylus are a total waste of time.

On the whole I love this phone. Other than a few nit picks above it does everything I want. You can keep your iPhones. I've used them all and this phone blows them away.

I have always purchased the best mobile phone available since my first in the mid 1990's. When Samsung launched the original Note I purchased my first Samsung handset. There were some issues, but that stylus was a game changer for me. From that moment on I have had Samsung devices, but not always Notes. Some models were too similar to the last in performance terms or just not safe (only the one) so I have also owned the S7 Edge and S10. This note 20 Ultra is superb, but there are some problems. 
First the camera/s.
The negatives...
I am a professional photographer so I seldom use the camera on my phone, but when I do I need it to be great quality and for it to operate quickly and reliably. The camera (and I imagine the software) on this phone are not good enough, I won't go into the obvious limitations of the optical design of the lenses being squeezed into an acceptable form factor, or the comparatively tiny sensors that need to be used. The bottom line is that if we strip away the bells and whistles of super wide angle and telephoto options and the ridiculously high pixel dimensions, the images my old Note 9 took (for my needs) are on the surface just as good as the Note 20. There is a ridiculous amount of interpolation going on (I just want optical 'zoom' please, not digital) the video at all resolution seems noisy and colour is rather strange at times.The killer issue is the speed... it is almost impossible to capture an image of ANTYHING that is not static. This needs to be resolved ASAP, the phone should not have come to market with this issue it is unacceptable
The positives...
The distortion control and auto exposure algorithms are very good, it is useful to have the extreme wide angle and the night shot images are superb, very well controlled on the luminance noise front which produces a very natural looking
image. Continuous AF and subject tracking are also very good (rendered useless with the glacial shutter lagg of course). Once the major flaws are resolved this phone will I'm sure capture superb imagery.
The other big issue is the screen. As usual images look superb on this device, however, only being able to reap the benefits of 120Hz at a much reduced resolution is very disappointing and more worrying is the flickering I have noticed at both 60Hz and 120Hz and different pixel dimensions. It has only happened a handful of times, very briefly, but I have never had this issue with any other Samsung handset. To summarise, superb build quality, superb design and features, but some very annoying and frankly disappointing flaws which I hope are just software related.

This is my first experience with the note brand.  I have previously has the S series, and my last one was a S10 plus ceramic edition.  The note has the same ultrasonic fingerprint reader and I find it 50/50in terms of reliability. Because of this I have registered both thumbs twice so that I have a better chance, and although this helps I don't think I should need to do this for a device that is priced quite high. The battery performance is also a little disappointing.  Again for such a high price point I was expecting a little more.  Another niggle would be that I am not able to have a higher screen resolution at 120hz, and there may be some battery management going on which is limiting the use of higher screen resolution with max refresh rate. The biggest gripe has to be that in the rest of the world we get the in-house Exynos chip, but compared with the Qualcom Snapdragon chip that is inferior.  I feel that for a device that is priced in this bracket, we should be getting the best chip battery life and refresh rate and max resolution.  Having said that apart from those gripes, the phone itself is a product that is nearly perfect.

I have had about 15 Android devices since 2009 and for the last 6 years I was exclusively using Google's own devices. But to be honest I was kinda getting bored with the oversimplicity of stock Android,  and I felt like jumping to a Samsung device again (my last was the S3). I have not been disappointed. I love the level of depth Samsung's One UI offers, while at the same time it's stylish and understated.
The Note 20 Ultra 5G has a great screen, great sound, great top end camera (I'm loving the zoom particularly) great build quality, but most of all is crammed packed with software features that I like. The Bixby routines are especially cool as they allow me to configure the device automatically depending on where I am or what I'm doing. The S pen is also a great feature to have. I have read that not all Note users actually make use of it, but I've found it really handy to take and store quick notes at work. The screen is so large that the device is certainly big enough to use as a notepad. The only thing about the phone that I would say could be better is the responsiveness and accuracy of the ultrasonic fingerprint sensor. I know it's more secure than a camera fingerprint sensor but it's just not as quick and reliable.
Still back to the good things - I have been impressed with Samsung's recent pledge to support its phones with 3 years of software and security updates. Coming from Pixel phones this was important to me and was the final thing I needed to hear to make me switch back to Samsung. So far I have been very impressed with the speed and regularity of the updates the phone has had.
All in all I would certainly recommend the Note 20 Ultra. It's the complete package and although it's not cheap, it's completely unique in what it offers. As I purchased it through Samsung's upgrade programme, I think I may now be sticking with Samsung devices for the foreseeable future.

Firstly, this is my first Note phone, as I usually stick to the flagship, Galaxy S series. However, I've been pleasantly surprised. 
Once you get used to the size of the device in your pocket, you are going to be happier for having this model. 
The most noticeable things are the screen resolution and quality, especially when watching sports; the ability to stream high quality without buffering, with the quickest refresh speed on social media that I've experienced. 
Another highlight for me is the camera. The quality of pictures and videos are great; however I am still tweaking and playing with the interface to find my perfect settings. The Ultra Zoom allowed me to take a photo of the moon (attached). It is good for portraits and group photos too (attached). 

The S-Pen is good. I've never had one before so initially I found it quite a gimmick, but there are uses - mainly for taking photos from a distance, but also if I'm sharing my phone with others but need to make sure I can quickly put them on the home screen if they stray to something they shouldn't see. 

I'm off to Mexico soon, and I'll be especially intrigued to see how this phone performs under water, taking videos and photos.

My granddaughter wears a lanyard stating hidden disability as she is severely sight impaired, her samsung galaxy note 10 plus 5g was stolen in mcdonald's. I purchased this phone as a replacement from argos because of the brilliant price and quick availability. She loves this new phone, she is enjoying using the new features that the software on the phone offers. She particularly loves the size of the size of the screen.

Been samsung boy since first ever phone which was still a flip phone.  Now an all note series fan. Cant wait to go all foldable when the tech evolve a bit. 
The phone itself. 
The screen. All I can say is you won't find anything like that. Its just the best. Colours,  contrast, Responsiveness, smoothness, brightness and the size. Curved edges, well I had them since s8  edge, cant remember what is flat screen. Speakers, man they totally blew me away. Loud, crisp, full and stereo mode is just a joy to watch content.
Cameras. Zoom, ultra wide, main camera. You got it. Nice crisp pictures. Sad to see dual aperture gone. The depth of field great. Focus, coming from note 9 I feel like its not 100% great but hey, the quality is much better of pictures and usually the struggle is when I try to take a close picture, I have to move it further focus and come close. However, no such issue if u use snapchat or Instagram, so I figure quick software tweak. 
Front facing camera. Its ok. Take selfies, focuses well quality is fine.
Battery life. Could be better. Last a day with average usage, but if you love to play games on highest setting (with amazing screen and good specs, who doesn't?) It will go fast. I do not think anyone would mind thicker phone and bigger battery, so samsung please.
Exynos and snapdragon. Seriously samsung explain why. Either make your exynos shine like the tech beast company you are or just give me snapdragon. Step up your the game. To be fair cannot see a single issue with phone speed. No lags and its powerhouse. I love playing games and watching movies at same time. If game is intense and video is high res. The game starts to lag and phone heats up like a stove. But, common watching movie and play game at same time on one device. Its fine. 5g, god I just love it. Half terabyte of storage, you are spoiling us. 
One ui. It is a heavy skin, nothing towards stock android. But it has evolved so much, the extra features, small tweaks here and there. Its a stock samsung. You either appreciate it or try something else.  But if you truly give it a try, you will find the appreciation for it. There is so much it offers you and you can make it as close to what you want as you can get. That to be said cant wait for you 3.0 version.
The design. It is stunning. I got the mystic black version. One sad thing, it doesn't have brushed glass feel, did not really knew when preordered that it is only for mystic bronze, would have gotten that maybe for a change. Camera bump doesn't feel anymore like an alien to the phone it is part of design and how its done its a stunner. The black colour is not your typical black. Its a changing colour from dark black to black grey. It looks great.
All in all it is a great phone. However, I can see that samsung is now getting focus on its new toy foldable. The company is all about innovation, can you blame them? While it is still in its infancy we have powerhouse note. Yes, I wish we had superior chipset (either better produced exynos or snapdragon), bigger battery, less bump or something else. But when I use this phone I do not think of them, all I think is God I love this phone.

I really love this phone! The build quality is exceptional and the cameras are awesome. Having come from a Note 9 I love the wide-screen angle lens and 5x optical zoom. The image quality is super.

The phone is really fast and doesn't often get warm although I don't do gaming.

The battery life was actually pretty poor when I first got the phone but has improved massively since after installing the Aug 1st update and doing a factory reset. I decided to do the latter anyway as decided on a fresh start with apps and settings.

I do think Samsung should have standardised on one processor for all markets, rather than Snapdragon for some regions and Exynos for others. Being in the UK I have the Exynos and have been concerned by some of the performance  comparisons. Having said that I do get about a day now out of it with moderate use but generally only charge it to 80% to put less stress on the battery.

I love the S Pen and find it incredibly useful for scribbling down thoughts and ideas whilst out and about.

The display is really superb.

All in all a fantastic phone.

I pre-ordered and got my new Note 20 Ultra 5G 2 days before general relase. SmartSwitch used to transfer my Note 10+ 5G to new phone. Boy, did it get hot (the Ultra 20). Disappointed, a dead spot on the screen that I could not use the S-Pen on.
Got a replacement on 02/09/20. Eagerly anticipating my new Note 20 Ultra. SmartSwitch used again, still got very hot. Guess what, same dead spot on phone. So dissappointed, I have requested a return and refund. I have used the Note since the 7 (sad but it got recalled), Note 8, Note 9 and Note 10+ 5G. Never have I been so dissapointed. Had a Samsung Galaxy S, S4, S6 and S8 before going the Note route. Come on Samsung, this is very poor.

Overall I'm really impressed with the phone compared to my note 10+ there is noticeable improvements even with one generation.

The only thing I'm a bit let down by is exynos processor which is vastly inferior to the snapdragon 865+ that our American counter parts get as the exynos processor runs hot and my battery life has been a bit sub par.

Overall the screen is amazing and cameras fantastic I just wish we get the better processor next year!

I've signed up for the Xbox xCloud service as I received the Game Pack with my pre-order, but experience so far has been really poor. The few games I've tried have been so laggy that they are unplayable.
Still, for everything I actually want to use the phone for it's really good. Just a slight evolution over the Note10+ 5G.

It's fast and takes good photos. I'm a big fan of the Note series and couldn't be without the stylus, to which this version is more responsive. 

However, the photos on the Samsung website his the fact that the camera lenses stick out at the back, by at least a third of the width of the main body of the phone. This makes it considerably chunkier when it's in the Samsung LED case, which could have made use of the void at the back below the lenses for multiple card storage. Out of its case, the protruding lens block seems vulnerable, making you extra careful where and how you put it down when you're not using it.

Without the protruding lenses I would have given it 5/5, and I probably would have waited for the next version with a flush camera unit had I known about it.

I decided to write this, as I am not happy with the my new phone and wanted to share it so others can have a better idea of what they are buying.

Starting from the positives, cool features such as the wireless dex (connect to TV and see phone apps on TV in a "desktop" User Interface), nice 5x zoom, 8k video etc.

Looking at the battery last 5 hours on the second day (no background cloud sync as I disabled that on the first day when I suspected it might be the issue) and every day really so not happy that I cannot have peace of mind of a single-day of battery life

I tried Dex for a few minutes (scared to see my phone getting hot) and I was impressed with it, although not sure if there is any practical use for most of the users.

Camera is impressive (night mode, 108MP pictures, video quality)

Only if the battery would last longer, I would increase performance and value ratings

Samsung have done a great job with the Note 20 Ultra 5g. The updated S-pen is a fantastic feature and has next to no lag. The camera is amazing, the night mode allows clear photographs in very low-light levels. The only fault I can raise is the battery: smaller capacity than the S20 and it fails to see out the day. Because of this, I don't make use of the reverse wireless charging for accessories. Luckily I have three of the super-fast chargers and 30 minutes sees the battery capacity up in the region of 50%.

The Note20 Ultra 5G feels like a step up from the Note10 Plus 5G. The S Pen feels a lot more natural, and the speed is fantastic. There's loads of features that just make every day easier like DeX being wireless and Live Caption. Link to Windows is also better than ever. Would recommend it to anyone.

After upgrading from the Galaxy S8, I do feel that not much has changed, other than the obvious such as the removing of the bezels, the camera, which I have not tried much and the added feature of an Spen. 
When I received the phone, I was excited to test out the Spen since I had been looking into buying a note as my next phone for a while. After 24 hours with the phone I am enjoying the added features of the Spen. I have begun making notes and organizing my files within the notes app, testing the app called PenUp and sent a couple of live messages. It works very smoothly and for me personally I do not mind having it on the left as it is my first experience with an Spen.
Batteries are something I have always had an issue with in the past, first on my S4 Mini and then my S8. Just days before my phone arrived I was watching reviews and finding that the battery was weak compared to other phones such as the S20 ultra. Now that it has arrived I am starting to notice that I will have to charge it as often as my S8, which was once a day and sometimes a small top up at night to make sure there was enough battery life for the next morning.
For the camera, which I have not tested much I found that it works well but as soon as you go past around 10X zoom it begins to get blurry. Even with a case which does extend past the large camera bump i'm still scared it will get damaged due to the amount that it sticks out of the phone.
Finally, I feel as though certain apps such as Snap chat have become a little blurry on this screen, although this may be the pre-installed screen protector. In addition to this, I found that many of the wallpapers provided on Galaxy Themes also look blurry on the larger screen and it took me almost an hour to find a suitable wallpaper which did not look too blurry, draining my battery a lot. 
Overall, for me this phone performs very well, my experience with the Spen has been very good so far, however the battery could be improved for such a powerful phone.

I pre-ordered the N20 ultra as soon as it was announced and was delighted when it arrived 2 days earlier than advertised!! I've had 24-hours with it now and have noticed many differences to my N10. The screen seems sharper, more colourful and maybe a little brighter? The phone feels slick and fast to use. Games run so much better. The S-Pen is absolutely brilliant this year. I had a go at dex on my smart TV, seemed to work fine. can't really say anything about the battery as it's still learning my usage pattern, seems about the same as my N10. I've noticed a massive improvement in notifications and using the phone as an actual 'phone' it seems like they've tied up all the loose ends from the previous model. Smart switch worked great, took about 25 minutes on my home Wi-Fi. All in all I really love it and to top it off it looks beautiful in hand as well. I have the mystic bronze, I've taken some pictures using my S6 tablet, they show the colour pretty much as it looks. Five stars from me, delighted with my purchase.
